utterances: You should see the inside; it's terrible.
They're salvaging what little they can from their water-logged rental (unintelligible)
We tried to save everything by throwing it up on the beds, but you can see it went over - it went over the bed.
December rains are common in the Pacific Northwest, but what happened this week was unusual.
A powerful Pacific storm brought hurricane-force winds to the Washington and Oregon coasts and dropped up to 10 inches of rain between Seattle and Portland.
In Lewis County in southwest Washington, it was too much for the Chehalis River to bear.
The river crested above record flood stage.
State trooper Todd Thornburg says this is the third time since 1990 this area has faced severe flooding, something the community never expected.
Three 100-year floods in 17 years.
It's still a little beat up by Mother Nature down here; just pretty devastating.
It's too early to know how many homes and businesses have been damaged or ruined in this sprawling semi-rural county.
But the governor plans to ask President Bush for a federal emergency declaration.
The longtime sheriff here, Steve Mansfield, says the damage is extensive.
But he notes people are pulling together.
It's been a real tragedy, but what you're seeing here is a lot of people helping each other out, so this is pretty cool.
This is about as good as it gets as far as an emergency disaster situation where something bad has happened.
In the nearby town of Chehalis, flood waters inundated a new shopping center that includes a Wal-Mart and a Starbucks.
Margaret Dunsmore(ph) wanted to take a row boat in to check on her tax business.
The National Guard said no.
I just want to take pictures of my office.
Unidentified Man: It's way too much of a danger.
There's so much stuff under that water that you can hit and sink...
Okay.
Dunsmore expects the worst but has an upbeat attitude.
Then I've heard that it was three or four feet, so it just means rebuilding, you know?
We're a service business so we'll just get the computers running again and we're good to go.
It's just, you know, ain't nothing but a thing.
You can't mess with Mother Nature when she comes along.
Back in the little community of Adna, the reality of what's happened is just hitting Rachel Jagger.
She doesn't know what she'll do next.
I don't know.
I'm still shock.
Just keep looking around.
I'm trying to make a list of everything that I lost, but it's overwhelming.
Judging from the looks of things, Jagger is far from alone.
For NPR News, I'm Austin Jenkins reporting.
Back now with DAY TO DAY.
We heard earlier from California's Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger about his efforts to be a green governor.

Last weekend was the Live Earth concerts around the world.
And then there's that Al Gore pledge; it's making its way around the Internet, sign on to the seven points to protest global warming.
Joining me for a slightly more irreverent take on all this green are Frangela - is Frangela, are Frangela?
Well, Frangela is two people.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Right here with me now, Frances Callier and Angela Shelton are comedic translators of current events.
Hi.
Thank you.
Thank you very much for using our correct title.
There's a lot of criticism about this concert.
Right.
You've got Madonna up there.
You've got some other stars, Cameron Diaz talking about using paper and not plastic, or whatever she's talking about.
And it just seems to be so fashionable, so hip.
Do you think it can of kind backfire, in a way?
Well, you know, I think, first of all, let me say I'm grateful for any time that Cameron Diaz isn't acting.
So right off the bat I'd like to thank the Live Earth people for that.

Yes, how does it help in the ozone?
Just tell me how to get from Point A to Point B on that one.
Well, you know, they say it's about raising awareness.
Yes.
